MY SIL MOVED IN WITH US WITH HER FAMILY AND MADE ME HER MAID, SO I BROUGHT HER DOWN TO EARTH.

My SIL Linda and her family moved in with us, because she was sick and they lost their house due to the expensive treatment.

Soon I found myself cooking, cleaning, and managing the household for eight people instead of four since she didn't help. She acted like the queen of the house, barking orders.

She’d leave dirty dishes everywhere and laundry piled up. I blamed everything on her illness.

Suddenly, she decided to host a party in our home, inviting people over, planning a menu, and assigning me tasks. I felt angry but agreed to help, thinking it could cheer her up.

MY HUSBAND JOKED IN FRONT OF HIS GUESTS THAT I WAS ON HIS MAINTENANCE AND HE'D KICK ME OUT IF I WASN'T OBEDIENT – HE LAUGHED ONLY FOR THE FIRST FEW MINUTES UNTIL MY EPIC REVENGE.

I met my husband, Gregor, when I was over 40. I wasn't looking for anything serious, but we hit it off immediately. Our first year of marriage was like a honeymoon.

Then I lost my job when my company went bankrupt, which was a huge blow. When I told Gregor, he was clearly annoyed.

“What, now I'm the breadwinner?” he said, dissatisfied.

Shocked, I quickly took a job as a cleaner to help us stay afloat.

Fast forward to Gregor’s 45th birthday. He threw a big party at a fancy restaurant. When his sister toasted to how lucky he was to have me, I felt touched.

Then Gregor stood up and said, "Oh, I know I'm lucky, but she's basically my dependent now. I'd have kicked her out if she wasn't so obedient. It's just a pity I invested all that money in her."

16:
So, there's this saying that the people we love the most are the ones who hurt us the most. That definitely happened to me.

I'm a firefighter. Once, I rescued a guy from a burning building and ended up with a nasty burn on my face. My wife couldn't handle it and eventually left me. But the worst part? My daughter, whom I was raising alone, was so embarrassed by my appearance that she didn't want anyone to know I was her dad.

One day, she blurted out, "I don't want my friends to see what a MONSTER you are! That's why mom left! I don't want to lose my friends too!"

She was only 8 when I got burned, and I thought she'd come around. But as the years went by, she remained embarrassed and distant.

I had pretty much given up hope and resigned myself to the situation when out of the blue, her classmates showed up at our door.👇
